summary: iDVGs naturally generated in vivo trigger potent lung antiviral immunity. mouse cells were infected either with SeV C containing high levels of copy-back iDVGs (SeV HD) or with SeV C depleted of iDVGs (SeV LD) or left untreated (N/T) and reinfected 6 h later with the unrelated IAV. IFNB1 mRNA expression and ratio of positive/negative-sense DVG RNA copy numbers determined by RT-qPCR from A549 cells infected with SeV HD at an MOI of 1.5 TCID50/cell. Experiments independently repeated at least three times. each assay was performed in triplicate. a predominant iDVG (DVG-546) present during infection with SeV HD (12, 34) correlated copy numbers of negative-sense DVG strands with IFNB1 mRNA expression. increased ratio of positive- to negative-sense DVG strands positively correlated with the induction of IFNB1 expression in infected human A549 cells. mutant DVG retained a shorter 5′ internal sequence (DVG-268). mutant DVGs lacking either the complete internal sequence (DVG-200) or both complementary sequences (DVG-IS) showed a reduced ability to stimulate antiviral genes upon transfection into both mouse and human cells. this differential activity of mutant DVGs was sustained over a 24 h time course. a temperature of 37°C was chosen to determine structures based on minimal free energy. the candidate motif (DVG70-114) is circled. the AU content of DVG70-114 is shown in the inset. we modeled in silico the folding of mutant DVGs with either a strong or a weak ability to induce type I IFN expression. we excluded the 3′ complementary sequence of the constructs because long complementarities strongly interfere with modeling based on minimal free energy. we identified a candidate stem-loop structure formed by nt 70 to 114 (DVG70-114) of DVG-546 that was observed only in mutant DVGs showing strong stimulatory ability. the difference was recapitulated in murine cells and sustained at the RNA and protein levels over a 24 h time course. a reduced ability to induce IFN production was also observed in DVG-54670-114. to further confirm the stimulatory role of DVG70-114, we introduced point mutations into this motif. infection with rDVG-324 stimulated significantly higher levels of IFNB1 and IFIT1 mRNA expression in LLC-MK2 cells. the viral protein and DVG RNA expression levels were equivalent (Fig. 3B). these data show that DVG70-114 functions to enhance the antiviral response during infection, demonstrating its biological relevance. LL-CMK2 cells were infected with SeV LD at an MOI of 1.5 TCID50/cell. expression of SeV NP and SeV (P/V) (C) and antiviral genes (D) was measured at 6 h posttransfection. the 3′ complementary end of iDVG RNA is not required for maximum IFN induction. we deleted the complete 3′ complementary sequence (94 nucleotides [nt] from DVG-324. both mutants showed higher potency than DVG-546. expression of IFNB1 mRNA by RT-qPCR in LLC-MK2 cells transfected for 6 h with 4.15 pmol of the ivtDVG indicated. the sequence of DVG5-51 is shown below the construct. Stabilization of the DVG70-114 motif enhances its stimulatory potential. we cloned the motif into the X region of HCV. the motif confers strong immunostimulatory activity to inert RNA molecules. tDVG RNA X region DVG70-114 (X region-based mutant that includes DVG70-114) led to strong expression of IFNB1 and IFIT1 mRNA. X region DVG70-114 also demonstrated an ability to stimulate antiviral gene expression equivalent to that of HCV poly(U/UC) (13). if the DVG70-114 motif augmented the binding of DVG RNA to RIG-I, we performed an electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) with DVG RNA exposed to purified RIG-I proteins that binds to RIG-I. lacked the signaling domain (RIG-I deltaCARD) we tested the binding affinity of RIG-I for iDVGs with or without DVG70-114 motif (DVG-268) in the absence or presence of ATP, which promotes RIG-I polymerization upon association with RNA. expression of IFNB1 mRNA by RT-qPCR of LLC-MK2 cells transfected for 6 h with 4.15 pmol of DVG-268 not treated (NT) or treated with RNase A, V1, A/V1 or mock transfected. all experiments in panel A to E were independently repeated at least three times.
